title: Data Science
text:
Powell Braddock
August 27, 2025
ST 558 - Homework 1

Let’s dive into what being a data scientist is all about: an interview with Powell

Q: What do you think being a data scientist is about?
A: Being a data scientist is about solving business problems using large amounts of data to create models that communicate major indicators as solutions.
Q: What differences/similarities do you see between data scientists and statisticians?
A: While statisticians infer significance in mainly batch or historical data, data scientists expand to real-time data. Data scientists also use more unstructured and unlabeled data, compared to statisticians.
Q: How do you view yourself in relation to these two areas?
A: I view myself as more of a data scientist than a statistician. Specifically, I see myself most interested in the role of data engineer, where I have an average amount of business/domain knowledge and engineering skills. While I have very developed statistical skills, I don’t feel as strongly about utilizing them on a day-to-day basis as I do my engineering skills. In my current job, I’m working on optimizing ETLs, which is challenging and exciting.



We can begin doing some R code
Our first chunk of code helps us determine the object y’s class, type, and structure.

y <- density(iris$Petal.Width)

class(y)

[1] "density"

typeof(y)

[1] "list"

str(y)

List of 8
 $ x         : num [1:512] -0.656 -0.648 -0.64 -0.633 -0.625 ...
 $ y         : num [1:512] 0.00161 0.00178 0.00197 0.00217 0.00239 ...
 $ bw        : num 0.252
 $ n         : int 150
 $ old.coords: logi FALSE
 $ call      : language density.default(x = iris$Petal.Width)
 $ data.name : chr "iris$Petal.Width"
 $ has.na    : logi FALSE
 - attr(*, "class")= chr "density"


Our second chunk of code uses the plot() function on the object y that was defined in the chunk prior. It has density on the y axis and the petal width on the x axis, with a specified value for both N and Bandwidth.
In order to ensure the code for this chunk does not print, we can specify echo as false.
